Trustee committee OK's $300 tuition hike
By BOB DANNER
President Muller received
approval from the Board of
Trustees Budget Committee last
Friday for a proposed $300 hike
in tuition for the coming school
year, 1975-76.
Muller, who pledged to keep
the cost at $3000 for at least one
Year after the 1973 rise, and did
so, said that a similar promise
could not be given to the
students this year.
"I can say nothing about
holding tuition at its present level
after this increase. Since I have
been president of the University,
the economic projections and the
outlooks for federal funds have
never been so uncertain."
"We arrived at that particular
amount through a blend of
Judgement, need, and
mathematics, always keeping a
feeling for what we thought the
parents and students would
tolerate," Muller continued.

Ellery Woodworth, Special
Assistant to the President, also
noted the economic necessity for
raising the tuition.
"The reasons for the increase
should be obvious to everyone
when you consider the 12
percent per year inflationary
spiral that we must keep pace
with."
The measure which only
awaits the "rubber stamp"
approval of the Board of Trustees
at their October. 14th meeting
amounts to a 10 percent increase
over the present $3000 tuition
rate, which went into effect two
years ago. This represents a 5
percent hike per year since 1973,
while prices in general were
growing at better than twice that
rate last year.
The trustees who attended the
budget committee meeting .were
Alonzo Decker, Gary Black,
Sheppard Hoffman, James N.
Shannon, and chairman of the

board, Robert Harvey.
Shannon, a young trustee who
graduated from Hopkins three
years ago stated that he thought
that the school had done all it
could to keep the rise as low as
possible.
"In raising tuition the
University has to be careful
about pricing itself into a
different market by cutting out
the middle class."
"We have not done this with
the planned increase. Ivy league
schools will have an average
tuition of about $3600," he
continued.
"I was struck by the sensitivity
of the University toward the
hardships that any increase
would place upon the students
and their parents," he added.
Muller flatly stated at an
earlier interview "I am more
interested in our own needs and
responsibilities than in other
institutions."

The increase passed the budget
committee without a dissenting
vote, although Hoffman, the
other young trustee had many
questions since lie was not on the
committee during the planning
stage.
Shannon made it clear that the
raise "was a direct result of the
federal cut in graduate student
aid but is more of a reflection of
the overall economic climate."
The tuition increase was

1974 Hopkins grad
To work in. admissions
Glen Thomas, Admissions
Director, announced yesterday
the appointment of Paul Jacques
Keene, a 1974 Hopkins graduate,
as Assistant Director of
Admissions here.
Keene will fill the void left by
two parting assistant directors,
Clark Dagett and Rubie Harris.
The number of assistant directors
now stands at five, as compared
to last year's total of six. .
Keene, who was selected from
an applicant pool of over 30, was
selected, to serve, in part, as a
minority recruiter for the school,
according to Thomas. Harris,
who like Keene is Black. had also
served unofficially in that
capacity.
However, Keene asserted that
he is not a minority recruiter. "I
am an admissions director," he
said; "Everyone will be trying to
do equally as much in terms of
minority recruitment."
In selecting Keene to replace.
Harris and Dagett, Thomas
indicated that he was looking for
a minority recruiter.

"We would like to think that
we could attract more minority
students to the University," said
Thomas. However, he pointed
out that there will be no major
changes in University recruitment
this year, only "refinement of
what we've been doing - at least
for this first year."
In addition to Keene's
appointment, Thomas revealed
the selection of John Morse as
Associate Director of Admissions
in late July. Morse filled Thomas'
old position when he became
Admissions Director.
Morse has had nine years
experience in admissions work,
and conies to Hopkins after
serving several years as Associate
director of Admissions at
Georgetown Unviersity.
Dagett leaves Hopkins after
only one year's stay in
admissions. He is departing
because he is moving into
another area of work, Thomas
said.

Anthropology department grows
By GAIL INGBER
The recently established
Anthropology department will
offer full undergraduate and
graduate programs next fall,
according to its chairman,
Professor Richard Price.
Price, formerly an associate
professor of anthropology at
Yale University; described this
academic year as "a transitional,
building one," and explained that
most of his time will be devoted
to building a library
collection
and hiring a staff for the
department.

Richard Price

The department will have
seven full-time faculty members,
all of whom will teach at both
the undergraduate and graduate
levels, Price said. The faculty
thus far is comprised of Professor
Sidney Mintz, who will specialize
in the Caribbean and economic
aspects of anthropology,
Associate Professor Emily Ahern,
specializing in China and religion,
and Adjunct Professor William C.
Sturtevant of the Smithsonian
Institute of Washington, D.C., in
addition to Price.
Price said that one of the seven
positions will be filled each year
by a different visiting professor.
He also revealed that next year's
visiting appointment would be
announced shortly.
"The three regular faculty
positions to be filled this fall will
hopefully include people who
specialize in West Africa, the
anthropology of symbolic forms,
anthropological linguistics, and
kinship and social structure,"
explained Price.
Although the department's full
prograin will not begin until next
fall, Price will teach an
undergraduate course next
semester. He said that the
undergraduate curriculum will
not be planned until the hiring of
the entire staff has been
completed, which Price estimates
will be sometime early next

semester.
"Requirements for prospective
majors will be worked out by
early spring," he said. "We also
hope our office on the third floor
of Maryland Hall will be
completed by then, if not much
sooner."
Atlantic history and culture
will be the department's primary
strength. Courses concerning
religion, mythology,
structuralism, and economics will
also be offered.

The recently announced tuition rise came as no shock to

University will continue to contribute to Hopkins as they

tuition down.

problem must come, like most solutions to current
catastrophes, from the federal government. Only with
workable and enduring solutions to the problems of
-inflation—if they do exist at all—can the battle of colleges for
life be won. In the meanwhile, we hope that the government
will consider the needs of those attending college, and render
aid through work-study programs, scholarships, tax-breaks,
and the like, so that higher education will remain open to
everyone, not just the wealthy.

The recently announced tuition rise came as no shock to
anyone. With inflation rising at a 14 per cent clip this year, a
10 per cent increase in tuition could be termed modest. Still,
the $300 jump is a tough pill to swallow, since families,just
like the University, must deal with the higher cost of living in
every other aspect of life.
What strikes us most about the hike is the futility that
people concerned must feel in response to it. Because of the
inflation, the University must up the tuition in order to
balance its budget. But because of the inflation students
cannot afford the increase. Like the inflationary spiral itself,
there seems to be no way out of the dilemma. •
All that students can hope for is that donors to the
University will continue to contribute to Hopkins as they
have in the past, and that University administrators will see
that as much money as possible is given towards keeping the
tuition down.
,The only real source of aid that can help alleviate the
problem must come, like most solutions to current
catastrophes, from the federal government. Only with
workable and enduring solutions to the problems of
-inflation—if they do exist at all—can the battle of colleges for
life be won. In the meanwhile, we hope that the government
will consider the needs of those attending college, and render
aid through work-study programs, scholarships, tax-breaks,
and the like, so that higher education will remain open to
everyone, not just the wealthy.
